column1: Sport makes a significant contribution to life today. The Sport Council estimates that Sport is currently worth 8 billion a year to the UK economy and 29 million people over the age of 16 regularly take part in sport or strenuous exercise. Recent government initiatives, backed by lottery funding have led to the development of many new facilities and initiatives in the UK. As a student, in addition to encouraging participation in sport the courses engage you in studying the biological and psychological influences of sport and through sociology how sport can influence and shape contemporary society.

There are many varied opportunities for graduates in Sport and Sport Coaching. In a vibrant and fast moving career you will be contributing as coaches, leaders and administrators from your local community to the sports and leisure industry.

The Division of Sport and Leisure has also become very proactive in the development of sport right across UAD. Sport at UAD has grown over the past four years along with the Division; more recreational activities are being programmed, our Sports Union teams are competing with more success on the national stage and our elite athletes programme is producing medal-winning performances in world and international events. Members of staff have been active in all aspects of sport and exercise in the University from facilitating the elite athletes in their attempts to excel in their chosen sport, and hosting prestigious sporting events, such as the BUSA Cross Country Championships, to encouraging the development of physical activities among all types of students. In such ways, the Division of Sport and Leisure is positively involved with developing sport and exercise throughout the University and the UK as a whole.
For more information on general sporting opportunities for Abertay students visit our website at www.abertay.ac.uk/sport.
BSc (Hons) Sport, Health and Exercise

If health through exercise and the opportunity to work towards international standing in your sport is at the top of your agenda, read on. This course is one of the most innovative, and one of the first of its kind, in Scotland. We are committed to helping talented athletes at the University achieve their full potential on and off the field.

You investigate the relationship between sport, health and exercise within contemporary society in order to understand the contribution of the public, private and voluntary bodies which support the development of sport in the UK. You learn about coaching models, talent identification, hydrotherapy and therapeutic exercise; how to design training programmes and analyse the effect of different playing surfaces on the body.

You study human development throughout a lifetime, starting with the anatomical development of young people, and covering the health problems associated with unhealthy eating, and the ageing process. To gain practical experience of the world of sport you attend a practical work placement at an establishment such as a professional sports club, leisure centre or hospital, working with professional athletes or on a community health project.
BSc (Hons) Sport Coaching and Development
If your interest in sport lies in the growing field of coaching and developing athletes our Sport Coaching and Development programme has been developed for you.

Students on the BSc (Hons) Sport Coaching and Development course study both coaching and development themes. Coaching themes involve the examination of coaching as a process and the concept of leadership. The development side includes policy and practice analysis, both national and local. You use comparative examples of coach education from the UK, USA and Australia to explore coaching models, the humanistic approach to coaching, mentoring and coach assessment and professional behaviour. Within the social context of coaching you examine sporting ethics, the legal responsibilities of a coach, motivational psychology and dealing with burnout in athletes.

Depending on your level of qualifications, you can enter this programme either at year 1, year 2 or year 3. If you hold a relevant Higher National Diploma (HND) you can apply to enter directly at year 2 level and upgrade your diploma to BSc (Hons) Sport Coaching and Development. This programme encourages you to build on the practical focus of your HND and to acquire the critical research, decision making and academic skills required of university graduates.
